subsection.title: "Clearing" Fractions
subsection.p: How can we solve an equation that involves algebraic fractions? Recall that to solve the equation \dfrac{3x}{4} = 9 we multiply both sides by 4 (the denominator of the fraction) to "clear" the fraction. \cancel{\blert{4}}(\dfrac{3x}{\cancel{4}}) \amp = (9)\blert{4} 3x \amp = 36 We can now finish the solution to get x=12.
We use the same idea to solve an equation with algebraic fractions.

solution.p: We multiply both sides of the equation by x, the denominator of the fraction, to get \cancel{\blert{x}}(\dfrac{5000+50x}{\cancel{x}}) \amp = (75)\blert{x} 5000+50x \amp = 75x Then we proceed as usual to finish the solution. We subtract 50x from both sides to find 5000 \amp = 25x 200 \amp = x You can check that x=200 does satisfy the equation.

subsection.title: Using an LCD to Clear Fractions
subsection.p: If an equation contains more than one fraction, we multiply both sides of the equation by the LCD of all the fractions. This will clear all the denominators at once.

warning.p: In , note that we multiplied each term by the LCD, 15, including terms that are not fractions, namely 2 in this example. Be sure to multiply each term of the equation by the LCD.

statement.p: When clearing fractions, which terms of the equation should we multiply by the LCD?

subsection.title: Variables in the Denominator
subsection.p: Equations that involve algebraic fractions can also be solved using an LCD.

solution.p: The LCD for the two fractions in the equation is \blert{4(x-5)}. We multiply both sides of the equation by the LCD. \blert{4(x-5)}\left(\dfrac{3}{4}\right) \amp = \left(8- \dfrac{2x+11}{x-5}\right) \cdot \blert{4(x-5)} ~~~~~~~~ \blert{\text{Apply the distributive law.}} \blert{\cancel{4}(x-5)}\left(\dfrac{3}{\cancel{4}}\right) \amp = \blert{4(x-5)}(8)- \blert{4\cancel{(x-5)}}\left(\dfrac{2x+11}{x-5}\right) 3(x-5) \amp = 32(x-5)-4(2x+11) We proceed as usual to complete the solution. First we use the distributive law to remove parentheses. 3x-15 \amp = 32x-160-8x-44 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Combine like terms.}} 3x-15 \amp = 24x-204 -21x \amp = -189 x \amp = 9 The solution is x=9. You can check that x=9 satisfies the original equation.

statement.p: How do we "clear" the fractions from an equation?

answer.p: Multiply both sides by the LCD.

assemblage.title: Look Ahead
assemblage.p: Remember that we do not obtain an equivalent equation if we multiply both sides of an equation by zero. In we multiplied by 4(x-5). Is it possible that 4(x-5) equals zero? After solving, we found that x=9, so 4(x-5) = 16, which is not zero, and the multiplication step was valid. The next example illustrates what can go wrong if we multiply by zero.

subsection.title: Extraneous Solutions
subsection.p: In , when we multiplied both sides of the equation by zero we found a false solution for the equation. Such solutions are called extraneous solutions. There is always a danger that an extraneous solution may be introduced when we multiply by an expression that contains the variable.

statement.p: When might an extraneous solution be introduced?

answer.p: When we multiply by an expression that contains the variable.

assemblage.p: We should always check for extraneous solutions when solving equations that involve algebraic fractions.

subsection.p: To check a solution, we substitute it into the original equation. If a possible solution causes any of the denominators in the equation to equal zero, then that solution is extraneous.

statement.p: How do we check for extraneous solutions?

answer.p: See if it causes any of the denominators in the equation to equal zero.

subsubsection.title: Activity 3: Work Problem
subsubsection.p: In this application, the work being done is the water flowing into (or out of) the reservoir, so the work rate is the flow rate of water through the pipes.

The city reservoir was completely emptied for repairs, and is now being refilled. Water flows in through the intake pipe at a steady rate that can fill the reservoir in 120 days. However, water is also being drained from the reservoir as it is used by the city, so that it actually takes 150 days to fill.
